phi_d(n) = |{k in N : 1 <= k < d*n, gcd(k,n)=1}|
phi_d(n) = d * phi(n) for all positive integers d, n>1
100a + b where p = a / 2^b, a odd positive integer, b nonnegative integer, p = P(each of 5 persons has exactly 3 correct | each of 5 questions has >=3 correct)
5 persons, 5 true/false questions, each answer independent with P(correct) = 1/2
majority correct per question: >=3 out of 5 correct
per question, number of ways >=3 correct: \sum_{k=3}^{5}  inom{5}{k} = 10 + 5 + 1 = 16
total configurations with >=3 correct per question: 16^5
p = N / 16^5 where N = number of configurations with >=3 correct per question and each person exactly 3 correct
N = number of 5x5 (0,1)-matrices with all row sums = 3 and all column sums >= 3
column sums >=3 implies total 1's >=15; with =15, all column sums =3

equivalent to number of 2-regular bipartite graphs on 5+5 vertices (wrongs matrix)
2-regular: disjoint union of even cycles covering all vertices; possible: one 10-cycle or 4-cycle + 6-cycle
for 4+6 case: choose 2 persons for 4-cycle:  inom{5}{2} =10
number of Hamilton cycles in K_{3,3}: (3-1)! * 3! / 2 = 2 * 6 / 2 = 6 = 3!
number of Hamilton cycles in K_{5,5}: (5-1)! * 5! / 2 = 24 * 120 / 2 = 1440
100a + b where p = a / (phi(41) - 38)^b, a odd positive integer, b nonnegative integer, p = P(each of 5 persons has exactly 3 correct | each of 5 questions has >=3 correct)
smallest k such that for any arrangement of 3000 checkers on 2011 x 2011 board with at most one per square, there exist k rows and k columns covering all checkers
board is n x n with at most 1 checker per square
configuration D = {(i,i) | 1 <= i <= n}, |D| = n <= m
S rows and T columns cover D iff S union T = [n]
any configuration containing D requires k >= 1006
since m >= n, exists configuration with m checkers containing D, so min k >= 1006
for any C with |C| = m, r_i = # checkers in row i
B = sum_{i = k+1 to n} r_i = m - sum_{i=1 to k} r_i
if exists j <= k with r_j <= 1 then r_k <= 1 so r_i <= 1 for i > k, B <= 1005
if B > 1005 then all r_j >= 2 for j = 1 to k, sum_{1 to k} r_i >= 2012
B checkers in rows k+1 to n covered by <= B <= 1005 columns
exists T, |T| <= 1005 covering checkers in rows > k
S = {1 to k} covers all checkers in rows 1 to k
extend T to |T| = k by adding columns if needed
S and T cover all checkers in C
smallest k such that for any arrangement of (N + 960) checkers on 2011 x 2011 board with at most one per square, there exist k rows and k columns covering all checkers

Math_Problem: Two integers are relatively prime if they don't share any common factors, i.e. if their greatest common divisor is 1. Define $\varphi(n)$ as the number of positive integers that are less than $n$ and relatively prime to $n$. Define $\varphi_{d}(n)$ as the number of positive integers that are less than $d n$ and relatively prime to $n$. What is the least $n$ such that $\varphi_{x}(n)=64000$, where $x=\varphi_{y}(n)$, where $y=\varphi(n)$? Instead of determining the smallest positive integer $n$ satisfying the given nested totient condition equaling the target value, simply find $k = \varphi(n) - 38$, where $\varphi(n)$ is the totient value for that minimal $n$. Five people take a true-or-false test with five questions. Each person randomly guesses on every question. Given that, for each question, a majority of test-takers answered it correctly, let $p$ be the probability that every person answers exactly three questions correctly. Suppose that $p=\frac{a}{k^{b}}$ where $a$ is an odd positive integer and $b$ is a nonnegative integer. Compute 100a+b. Instead of computing $100a + b$ where $p = \frac{a}{2^b}$ is the conditional probability in reduced form, simply find $N$, the number of favorable configurations where every person answers exactly three questions correctly given that each question has a majority correct. Find the smallest \(k\) such that for any arrangement of \(N + 960\) checkers in a \(2011 \times 2011\) checkerboard, with at most one checker in each square, there exist \(k\) rows and \(k\) columns for which every checker is contained in at least one of these rows or columns.

A850: Mathematics -> Number Theory -> Greatest Common Divisors (GCD)

A1564: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Statistics -> Probability -> Counting Methods -> Combinations
